ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

The MPLX Terminals, LLC - Mt. Vernon LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Mt. Vernon LP Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used for the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Mt. Vernon, IN. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low sulfur diesel/#2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various petroleum-based additives.

The Mt. Vernon LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand-in-hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. MPLX promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX has designed and implemented at the Mt. Vernon LP Terminal including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances.
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs.
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals.
D. An overview of the emergency response program.
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Butane Fuel Blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is n

ecessary to observe certain safety precautions during handling to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.  Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Butane Fuel Blending Process.

The Butane Fuel Blending process is a batch-type process based on seasonal RVP adjustments. Butane is received by truck (transports) and piped directly to and injected into the gasoline barge-loading lines. Process safety controls for the offloading skid that are used include emergency shutoff valves with a fusible element (rated at < 250 deg. F) and local/remote manual actuation; plus, a check valve for instantaneous closure in the event of a pull-away event.  A "Smart Hose" with engineered breakaway capabilities plus self-closing valves at each connection point is also utilized.  Other protective measures/system controls include pipe thermal/hydrostatic reliefs, grounding, vessel pressure reliefs, vessel excess flow valves, and high-level shutdowns.  A deluge system with manifold is available to the fire department to facilitate vessel cooling water application.  Access to the Facility is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel, and approved contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES

The Mt. Vernon LP Terminal accidental release prevention and emergency planning/response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the regulated substance to the Terminal employees, surrounding public, and environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119. The f

eak-away and self-closing valves on each end.

General Emergency Response:

-Emergency alert system;
-Periodic emergency training for employees;
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies; and
-Emergency drills/training with Terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.

Further, the Mt. Vernon LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP)/"Smart Plan" is in place for the Facility with response activities being coordinated with the Black Township Fire Department (primary responder) and the Posey County LEPC.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Mt. Vernon LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal keeps records for all incidental and significant chemical releases inclusive of any root cause analyses and associated follow-up actions, where appropriate.  As this is a new process, there have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the release of materials resulting in consequences covered under the EPA RMP reporting requirements.  The Terminal tracks all process safety events/incidents per API 754.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Mt. Vernon LP Terminal is identified as a "non-responding stationary source".  As previously noted, the Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Black Township Fire Department (primary responder) and Posey County Emergency Management Agency (LEPC.) An ERAP/"Smart Plan" is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release or fire including implementation of emergency response notification procedures.

In the event of an emergency involving the Mt. Vernon LP Terminal Butane Fuel Blending system, it is the

policy of the Facility to shutdown all Terminal processes and initially contact the Black Township Fire Department to request their assistance.

At a minimum, the Black Township Fire Department/Posey County LEPC participates in annual butane training/coordination sessions and notification exercises.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

MPLX is continually striving to make the Mt. Vernon LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, MPLX actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements. All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT) per corporate policy.  Additionally, the Mt. Vernon Terminal is evaluating additional/improved emergency power capabilities for the process.
